direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, wait a minute. I know what you're thinking -- but it's not as bad as it looks -- MATUSCHKA (shoving him away) It's none of my business what you do, Fran -- you're over twenty- one -- but your sister happens to think you're a lady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All we were going to do is eat and wash the dishes -- MATUSCHKA (grabbing him) Look, Buddy-boy -- if there wasn't a lady present, I'd clobber you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (separating them) All right, Karl -- I'll get dressed. She exits into the bedroom, removing her dress from the door, and closing it. Matuschka leans against the wall beside the hall door, eyeing Bud truculently. Bud raises a finger to remonstrate with him -- then breaks into a nervous, ingratiating smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Care for a martini? Champagne? (Matuschka continues glaring at him) How about a little spaghetti with meat sauce? Made it myself. (Matuschka just scowls) Your sister-in-law sure is terrific -- (realizes his mistake; switching abruptly) Must be murder driving a cab in New York -- I mean, with all that cross-town traffic -- He gestures with the martini glass, spilling the contents over his shirtfront. Through the partly open hall door, Dr. Dreyfuss sticks his head in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Baxter. He steps into the apartment, passing Matuschka without seeing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's the patient?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (quickly) Oh, I'm fine, Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not you -- Miss Kubelik.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stepping forward) What's the matter with Miss Kubelik?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, this is Mr. Matuschka -- he's Miss Kubelik's -- he's got a cab downstairs -- MATUSCHKA (to Dreyfuss) Fran been sick or something? Dr. Dreyfuss looks at Bud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no -- just had a little accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Dreyfuss) What does he mean, accident?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, these things happen all the time -- MATUSCHKA What things? (grabbing Dreyfuss) Say, what kind of doctor are you, anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hastily) Oh, not that kind. He just gave her a shot and pumped her stomach out -- Behind them, the bedroom door has opened, and Fran comes out, wearing her coat over her dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (coming up) Because I took some sleeping pills. But I'm all right now -- so let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you take sleeping pills?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (promptly) On account of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whirling on him) You?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who else? Matuschka lashes out with a left to Bud's jaw, and while he is off balance, catches him with a right to the eye. Bud falls back against the Christmas tree, which topples with a crash. Fran pulls Matuschka away from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave him alone, Karl. She kneels beside Bud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (tenderly) You fool -- you damn fool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Fran.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, Mr. Baxter. She kisses him on the cheek, rises, starts toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, doctor. She follows Matuschka out. Bud looks after her, starry-eyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to gloat, but just between us, you had that coming to you. (tilts Bud's chin up, examines his eye) Tch, tch, tch. Are you going to have a shiner tomorrow. Let me get my bag. (he starts out)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calling after him) Don't bother, Doc. It doesn't hurt a bit. He is on Cloud Nine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Mr. Sheldrake's office? This is C.C. Baxter. Would you please tell Mr. Sheldrake I'd like to come up and see him? It's rather important. Will you call me back, please? He hangs up, takes off his hat and coat, deposits them on the clothes- tree. Then he paces around the office, rehearsing a speech out loud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you. All your troubles are over. I'm going to take Miss Kubelik off your hands. (nods to himself with satisfaction) The plain fact is, Mr. Sheldrake, that I love her. I haven't told her yet, but I thought you should be the first to know. After all, you don't really want her, and I do, and although it may sound presumptuous, she needs somebody like me. So I think it would be the thing all around -- (the phone rings and he picks it up)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. LOBBY INSURANCE BUILDING - DAY It is mid-afternoon, and traffic is light. A Yellow Cab has pulled up in front of the entrance, and the driver, a stockily-built young man in a leather jacket and cap, gets out and comes through the revolving doors into the lobby. His name is KARL MATUSCHKA, and he is Fran's brother-in-law. As he cases the elevators, the starter comes up to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. THE APARTMENT - EVENING Buddy-boy is bending over a hot stove, preparing an Italian dinner. He takes a saucepan of spaghetti off the fire, and picking up the tennis racquet with the other hand, pours the spaghetti on top of the racquet strings. Then he turns on the faucet, runs water over the spaghetti. With the combined technique of Brillat-Savarin and Pancho Gonzales, he gently agitates the racquet, letting the water drain off the spaghetti. As he works, he hums a theme from Tschaikowsky's Capriccio Italien. Fran walks in, still in her robe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : FADE IN: INT. NINETEENTH FLOOR - DAY Bud is coming from the elevators toward his office. He is wearing his chesterfield, bowler, and a pair of dark glasses. He opens the office door, starts in. INT. BUD'S OFFICE - DAY Bud crosses directly to the phone, removes his glasses revealing a swollen left eye. He dials a number.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: solution-wise. (into phone) Yes? I'll be right up. He hangs up, crosses to the door, opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to himself) Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you -- Putting on his dark glasses, he heads for the elevators, still talking to himself. INT. NINETEENTH FLOOR - DAY Kirkeby and Dobisch are just stepping out of an elevator when Bud approaches. They grin smugly when they see that he is wearing dark glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Buddy-boy. What happened to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit by a swinging door? Or maybe a Yellow Cab? Bud pays no attention, walks right past them into the elevator, still muttering to himself. The doors close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as they move away from the elevators) That guy really must've belted him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, he's punchy. Talking to himself. INT. TWENTY-SEVENTH FLOOR FOYER - DAY The elevator doors open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty-seven. Bud steps out. As he heads for Sheldrake's office, he continues rehearsing his speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, Mr. Sheldrake, those two days she spent in the apartment -- it made me realize how lonely I'd been before. But thanks to you, I'm in a financial position to marry her -- if I can ever square things with her family. He opens the door to Sheldrake's anteroom. INT. SHELDRAKE'S OFFICE - DAY Sheldrake is pacing in front of his desk. A couple of suitcases are standing in a corner of the room. The intercom buzzes, and Sheldrake presses the lever down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Baxter is here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Send him in. A beat, then the door opens, and Bud marches in determinedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you -- SHELDRAKE And I've got good news for you, Baxter. All your troubles are over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reacting to the echo) Sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know how worried you were about Miss Kubelik -- well, stop worrying -- I'm going to take her off your hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stunned) You're going to take her off my hands?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. (indicating suitcases) I've moved out of my house -- I'm going to be staying in town, at the Athletic Club.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You left your wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if you must know -- I fired my secretary, my secretary got to my wife, and my wife fired me. Ain't that a kick in the head?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah -- SHELDRAKE Now what was your news, Baxter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (recovering with difficulty) It's about Miss Kubelik -- she's all right again -- so she went back home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swell. And don't think I've forgotten what you did for me. (opens door to adjoining office) This way, Baxter. Bud advances slowly toward the door. INT. ADJOINING OFFICE - DAY It is a slightly smaller and less lavish edition of Sheldrake s office. Sheldrake ushers Bud through the door, points to the chair behind the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down. Try it on for size. Bud obeys like an automaton, lowers himself into the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like? (indicating office) It's all yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My assistant, Roy Thompson, has been shifted to the Denver office, and you're taking his place. (no reaction from Bud) What's the matter, Baxter? You don't seem very excited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's just that so many things have been happening so fast -- I'm very pleased -- especially for Miss Kubelik. Now that I've gotten to know her better, I think she's the kind of girl that definitely ought to be married to somebody -- SHELDRAKE Oh, sure, sure. But first the property settlement has to be worked out -- then it takes six weeks in Reno -- meanwhile, I'm going to enjoy being a bachelor for a while. (starts back toward his own office) Oh, by the way, you can now have lunch in the executive dining room -- BUD Yes, sir. He removes his dark glasses reflectively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's just one of the privileges that goes with this job. You also get a nice little expense account, the use of the executive washroom -- (breaks off, peers at Bud's face) Say, what happened to you, Baxter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got kicked in the head, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh? With a shrug, he exits into his own office, closing the door behind him. Bud sits there, unconsciously bending the glasses in his hand until they suddenly snap in two. Bud glances down at the two broken halves, as though surprised by his own violence, tosses them on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, Mr. Baxter. Bud turns to her in surprise, removes his bowler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Miss Kubelik. How do you feel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. How's your eye?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. There is a moment of constraint between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's everything at the apartment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing's changed. You know, we never finished that gin game -- FRAN I know. (a beat) I suppose you heard about Mr. Sheldrake --?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean, leaving his wife? Yeah. I'm very happy for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never thought he'd do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you all along. You see, you were wrong about Mr. Sheldrake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For that matter, you were wrong about me, too. What you said about those who take and those who get took? Well, Mr. Sheldrake wasn't using me -- I was using him. See? (indicating his name on directory) Last month I was at desk 861 on the nineteenth floor -- now I'm on the twenty-seventh floor, paneled office, three windows -- so it all worked out fine -- we're both getting what we want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (looks at her watch) You walking to the subway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you. (fumbling)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. LOBBY INSURANCE BUILDING - EVENING We are close on the building directory. Listed under PERSONNEL is J.D. SHELDRAKE, Director, and just below that a man's hand is inserting the name C.C. BAXTER in the slot marked Asst. Director. The lettering is complete except for the final R. Camera pulls back to reveal the sign painter we saw earlier, working on the directory. Watching him is Bud. He is wearing his chesterfield and bowler, and still has a slight welt under his left eye. It is after six o'clock, and there is very little activity in the lobby. Fran, wearing her coat over street clothes, approaches from the direction of the elevators, stops when she sees Bud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: well, to tell you the truth -- (glancing around lobby)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have this heavy date for tonight -- He points off toward the newsstand. Standing there is a tall, attractive brunette, obviously waiting for someone. Fran looks off in the indicated direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't you meeting Mr. Sheldrake?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. You know how people talk. So I decided it would be better if we didn't see each other till everything is settled, divorce-wise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's very wise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, Mr. Baxter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, Miss Kubelik. Fran walks toward the revolving doors. Bud watches her for a moment, then strides briskly across the lobby toward the newsstand. He goes right past the waiting brunette, stops in front of a rack of pocket books, examines the merchandise. A man now comes out of a phone booth, joins the waiting brunette, and they go off together. Bud picks out a couple of paperbacks, pays the clerk behind the counter. Stuffing a book into each coat pocket, he moves slowly toward the revolving doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baxter -- would you mind stepping in her for a minute?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Sheldrake. The bootblack finishes the second shoe with a flourish, gathers up his equipment. Sheldrake tosses him a half dollar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Much obliged. He exits into the anteroom as the door of the adjoining office opens and Bud comes in, carrying several charts. There is no trace left of his black eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (putting charts on desk) Here's the breakdown of figures on personnel turnover. Thirty-seven percent of our female employees leave to get married, twenty-two percent quit because -- SHELDRAKE (breaking in) You're working too hard, Baxter. It's New Year's Eve -- relax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose you'll be on the town tonight -- celebrating?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naturally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, too. I'm taking Miss Kubelik out -- I finally talked her into it -- BUD I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The only thing is I'm staying at the Athletic Club -- and it's strictly stag so if you don't mind -- BUD Don't mind what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know that other key to your apartment -- well, when we had that little scare about Miss Kubelik, I thought I'd better get rid of it quick -- so I threw it out the window of the commuter train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very clever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I'll have to borrow your key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, Mr. Sheldrake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean, sorry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not going to bring anybody up to my apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not just bringing anybody -- I'm bringing Miss Kubelik.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Especially not Miss Kubelik.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's that again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (flatly) No key!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baxter, I picked you for my team because I thought you were a bright young man. You realize what you're doing? Not to me -- but to yourself. Normally it takes years to work your way up to the twenty-seventh floor -- but it takes only thirty seconds to be out on the street again. You dig?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nodding slowly) I dig.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what's it going to be? Without taking his eyes off Sheldrake, Bud reaches into his pocket, fishes out a key, drops it on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you're being bright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, sir. He turns abruptly, starts back into his own office. INT. BUD'S NEW OFFICE - DAY Bud comes in, shutting the door behind him, stands rooted to the spot for a moment. Then he takes some pencils out of his breast pocket and drops them into a container on the desk, closes his account book, slams a couple of open file drawers shut. As he crosses to the clothes closet, the connecting door opens and Sheldrake comes in, key in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say, Baxter -- you gave me the wrong key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No I didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (holding it out) But this is the key to the executive washroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, Mr. Sheldrake. I won't be needing it -- because I'm all washed up around here. He has taken his chesterfield and bowler out of the closet, and is putting the coat on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's gotten into you, Baxter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just following doctor's orders. I've decided to become a mensch. You know what that means? A human being.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now hold on, Baxter -- BUD Save it. The old payola won't work any more. Goodbye, Mr. Sheldrake. He opens the door to the anteroom, starts out. INT. SHELDRAKE'S ANTEROOM - DAY Bud comes out of his office, carrying his bowler, strides past the secretaries and through the glass doors to the foyer. An elevator is just unloading, and beside it a handyman is cleaning out one of the cigarette receptacles. Bud crosses to the elevator, and as he passes the handyman, he jams his bowler on the man's head -- surrendering his crown, so to speak. The elevator doors close. The handyman straightens up, looks around in bewilderment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say, Baxter -- we're having a little party and we ran out of ice -- so I was wondering -- BUD Sure, Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stepping inside) How come you're alone on New Year's Eve?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I have things to do -- DR. DREYFUSS (noticing cartons) What's this -- you packing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah -- I'm giving up the apartment. He goes into the kitchen, opens the refrigerator, starts to pry out the ice-cube trays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you moving to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. All I know is I got to get out of this place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry to lose you, Baxter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? Oh, you mean my body. Don't worry, Doc -- it'll go to the University -- I'll put it in writing -- He dumps the ice-cubes, still in their trays, into the bucket Dr. Dreyfuss is holding. Then he pulls Kirkeby's unopened bottle of champagne out of the refrigerator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you use a bottle of champagne?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Booze we don't need. Why don't you join us, Baxter? We got two brain surgeons, an ear, nose and throat specialist, a proctologist, and three nurses from Bellevue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thanks -- I don't feel like it. Look, Doc -- in case I don't see you again -- how much do I owe you for taking care of that girl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget it -- I didn't do it as a doctor -- I did it as a neighbor. (stopping in doorway) By the way, whatever happened to her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (airily) You know me with girls. Easy come, easy go. Goodbye, Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happy New Year. Bud closes the door, returns to the kitchen, brings out a box of glassware and the tennis racquet. As he starts to deposit the racquet in a carton, he notices a strand of spaghetti clinging to the strings. He removes it gently, stands there twirling the limp spaghetti absently around his finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry it took me so long on the phone. But we're all set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All set for what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I rented a car -- it's going to be here at one o'clock -- we're driving to Atlantic City.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Atlantic City?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's a drag -- but you can't find a hotel room in town -- not on New Year's Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a long look at Sheldrake) Ring out the old year, ring in the new. Ring-a-ding-ding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't plan it this way, Fran -- actually, it's all Baxter's fault.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baxter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wouldn't give me the key to the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wouldn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just walked out on me -- quit -- threw that big fat job right in my face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a faint smile) The nerve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That little punk -- after all I did for him! He said I couldn't bring anybody to his apartment -- especially not Miss Kubelik. What's he got against you, anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a faraway look in her eye) I don't know. I guess that's the way it crumbles -- cookie-wise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd spell it out for you -- only I can't spell. The piano player is consulting the watch on his upraised left arm. He drops the arm in a signal, and the lights go out. At the same time, he strikes up AULD LANG SYNE. All over the dimly lit room, couples get to their feet, embracing and joining in the song. In the last booth, Sheldrake leans across the table, kisses Fran.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happy New Year, Fran. Fran's expression is preoccupied. Sheldrake faces in the direction of the pianist, and holding his glass aloft, sings along with the others. As AULD LANG SYNE comes to an end, the place explodes noisily -- there is a din of horns, ratchets, and shouted greetings. The lights come up again. In the last booth, Sheldrake turns back toward Fran -- but she is no longer there. Her paper hat lies abandoned on her vacated chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fran -- (looking around)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. SHELDRAKE'S OFFICE - DAY Sheldrake is swiveled around sideways behind his desk, with a bootblack kneeling in front of him, shining his shoes. Reaching for the intercom, Sheldrake presses down one of the levers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. THE APARTMENT - NIGHT Bud is in the process of packing. In the middle of the living room are several large cardboard cartons filled with his possessions. The art posters are off the walls, the bric-a-brac has been removed from the shelves, and Bud is stowing away the last of his books and records. He crosses to the fireplace, opens one of the drawers in the cabinet above it, takes out a forty-five automatic. He holds the gun in the palm of his hand, studies it appraisingly. The doorbell rings. Bud snaps out of his reverie, drops the gun into one of the cartons, goes to the door and opens it. Standing outside is Dr. Dreyfuss, with a plastic ice bucket in his hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. CHINESE RESTAURANT - NIGHT It is five minutes before midnight, New Year's Eve. Sitting alone in the last booth is Fran, a paper hat on her head, a pensive look on her face. There are two champagne glasses on the table, and the usual noisemakers, but the chair opposite her is empty. Above the general hubbub, the Chinese pianist can be heard playing. After a moment, Fran glances off. Threading his way through the merrymakers crowding the bar and overflowing from the booths is Sheldrake. He is in dinner clothes, topped by a paper hat. Reaching the last booth, he drops into the chair facing Fran.
dialogue.name: dialogue
